mn67:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Cātumā in a myrobalan grove.
mn67:3.3: Now at that time five hundred mendicants headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna arrived at Cātumā to see the Buddha.
mn67:3.4: And the visiting mendicants, while exchanging greetings with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.
mn67:3.5: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda:
mn67:3.6: “Ānanda, who’s making that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
mn67:3.7: And Ānanda told him what had happened.

mn67:3.14: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha,

mn67:3.17: “Mendicants, what’s with that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
mn67:3.18: And they told him what had happened.
mn67:3.20: “Go away, mendicants, I dismiss you. You are not to stay in my presence.”
mn67:3.21: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They got up from their seats, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. They set their lodgings in order and left, taking their bowls and robes.

mn67:4.6: “Sirs, the mendicant Saṅgha has been dismissed by the Buddha.”

mn67:4.9: Then the Sakyans of Cātumā went up to the Buddha,

mn67:4.12: “May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!
mn67:4.13: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!
mn67:4.14: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!

mn67:6.1: The Sakyans of Cātumā and Brahmā Sahampati were able to restore the Buddha’s confidence with the similes of the seedlings and the calf.
mn67:6.2: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants:
mn67:6.3: “Get up, reverends, and pick up your bowls and robes.
mn67:6.4: The Buddha’s confidence has been restored.”
mn67:6.5: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and, taking their bowls and robes, went to the Buddha,
mn67:6.6: bowed, and sat down to one side.
mn67:6.7: The Buddha said to Venerable Sāriputta:
mn67:6.8: “Sāriputta, what did you think when the mendicant Saṅgha was dismissed by me?”
mn67:6.10: ‘The Buddha has dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha.
mn67:6.11: Now he will remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in the present life, and so will we.’”
mn67:6.12: “Hold on, Sāriputta, hold on! Don’t you ever think such a thing again!”
mn67:6.13: Then the Buddha addressed Venerable Mahāmoggallāna:
mn67:6.14: “Moggallāna, what did you think when the mendicant Saṅgha was dismissed by me?”
mn67:6.16: ‘The Buddha has dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha.
mn67:6.17: Now he will remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in the present life. Meanwhile, Venerable Sāriputta and I will lead the mendicant Saṅgha.’”
mn67:6.19: For either I should lead the mendicant Saṅgha, or else Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”
mn67:7.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
mn67:7.2: “Mendicants, when you go into the water you should anticipate four dangers.
mn67:7.4: The dangers of waves, crocodiles, whirlpools, and sharks.
mn67:7.5: These are the four dangers that anyone who enters the water should anticipate.
mn67:7.6: In the same way, a respectable person who goes forth from the lay life into homelessness in this teaching and training should anticipate four dangers.
mn67:7.8: The dangers of waves, crocodiles, whirlpools, and sharks.
mn67:8.1: And what, mendicants, is the danger of waves?
mn67:8.2: It’s when a respectable person has gone forth from the lay life into homelessness, thinking:
mn67:8.3: ‘I’m overwhelmed by birth, old age, and death; by sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m overwhelmed by suffering, mired in suffering.
mn67:8.4: Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
mn67:8.5: When they’ve gone forth, their spiritual companions advise and instruct them:
mn67:8.6: ‘You should go out like this, and come back like that. You should look to the front like this, and to the side like that. You should contract your limbs like this, and extend them like that. This is how you should bear your outer robe, bowl, and robes.’
mn67:8.8: ‘Formerly, as laypeople, we advised and instructed others.
mn67:8.9: And now these mendicants—who you’d think were our children or grandchildren—imagine they can advise and instruct us!’
mn67:8.10: They abandon the training and return to a lesser life.
mn67:8.11: This is called one who abandons the training and returns to a lesser life because they’re afraid of the danger of waves.
mn67:8.12: ‘Danger of waves’ is a term for anger and distress.
mn67:9.1: And what, mendicants, is the danger of crocodiles?
mn67:9.2: It’s when a respectable person has gone forth from the lay life into homelessness, thinking:
mn67:9.3: ‘I’m overwhelmed by birth, old age, and death; by sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m overwhelmed by suffering, mired in suffering.
mn67:9.4: Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
mn67:9.5: When they’ve gone forth, their spiritual companions advise and instruct them:
mn67:9.6: ‘You may eat, consume, taste, and drink these things, but not those. You may eat what’s allowable, but not what’s unallowable. You may eat at the right time, but not at the wrong time.’
mn67:9.19: ‘When we were laypeople, we used to eat, consume, taste, and drink what we wanted, not what we didn’t want.
mn67:9.23: We ate and drank both allowable and unallowable things, at the right time and the wrong time.
mn67:9.31: And these faithful householders give us a variety of delicious foods at the wrong time of day. But these mendicants imagine they can gag our mouths!’
mn67:9.32: They abandon the training and return to a lesser life.
mn67:9.33: This is called one who abandons the training and returns to a lesser life because they’re afraid of the danger of crocodiles.
mn67:9.34: ‘Danger of crocodiles’ is a term for gluttony.
mn67:10.1: And what, mendicants, is the danger of whirlpools?
mn67:10.2: It’s when a respectable person has gone forth from the lay life into homelessness, thinking:
mn67:10.3: ‘I’m overwhelmed by birth, old age, and death; by sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m overwhelmed by suffering, mired in suffering.
mn67:10.4: Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
mn67:10.5: When they’ve gone forth, they get dressed in the morning and, taking their bowl and robes, enter a village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.
mn67:10.6: There they see a householder or their child amusing themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn67:10.8: ‘Formerly, as laypeople, we amused ourselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn67:10.9: And it’s true that my family is wealthy.
mn67:10.10: I can both enjoy my wealth and make merit.’
mn67:10.11: They abandon the training and return to a lesser life.
mn67:10.12: This is called one who abandons the training and return to a lesser life because they’re afraid of the danger of whirlpools.
mn67:10.13: ‘Danger of whirlpools’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn67:11.1: And what, mendicants, is the danger of sharks?
mn67:11.2: It’s when a respectable person has gone forth from the lay life into homelessness, thinking:
mn67:11.3: ‘I’m overwhelmed by birth, old age, and death; by sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m overwhelmed by suffering, mired in suffering.
mn67:11.4: Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
mn67:11.5: When they’ve gone forth, they get dressed in the morning and, taking their bowl and robes, enter a village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.
mn67:11.6: There they see a female scantily clad, with revealing clothes.
mn67:11.8: so they abandon the training and return to a lesser life.
mn67:11.9: This is called a mendicant who abandon the training and returns to a lesser life because they’re afraid of the danger of sharks.
mn67:11.10: ‘Danger of sharks’ is a term for females.
mn67:11.11: These are the four dangers that a respectable person who goes forth from the lay life into homelessness in this teaching and training should anticipate.”
mn67:12.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn67:12.2: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
